title: Boris Johnson: US should reconsider immunity over fatal crash
text:
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson | Peter Summers/Getty Images Boris Johnson: US should reconsider immunity over fatal crash The prime minister’s spokesperson told journalists the British foreign secretary has spoken to the US ambassador.

LONDON — Boris Johnson has urged the U.S. to reconsider giving immunity to the wife of one of its diplomats who is a suspect in a fatal road crash in the U.K.

Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has spoken to U.S. Ambassador Woody Johnson following the death of teenager Harry Dunn, who died when his motorbike collided with a car near an RAF base in Northamptonshire on August 27, the prime minister's spokesperson said on Monday.

The U.S. diplomat's wife, named as Anne Sacoolas, left the U.K. despite telling police she had no plans to, the BBC reported.

At a regular briefing for journalists in Westminster on Monday, the spokesman said the details of the case were "extremely concerning."

"The justice process should be allowed to take place and we urge the U.S. to reconsider their decision," he said.

Johnson offered his condolences to the Dunn family, the spokesperson added. "This was a tragic set of events which no family should have to experience."

Raab is due to meet the Dunn family, with details currently being finalized.
description: The prime minister’s spokesperson told journalists the British foreign secretary has spoken to the US ambassador.
